title: 103_s394
content: Credit for payments or contributions to certain cooperative research organizations. The amendment allows for a 50 percent credit on qualified cooperative research expenditures. The amendment defines qualified cooperative research expenditures as contributions to research consortia for qualified research. The term 'expenditures' refers to the total amount of qualified contributions to research consortia for qualified research, with limitations on private source funding. The taxpayer's qualified contributions to research consortia for qualified research are subject to a private source funding limitation based on the private source funding ratio. The private source funding ratio is determined based on the organization's gross receipts excluding governmental support, with a 50 percent weight. The private source funding ratio is calculated by taking a percentage of the organization's gross receipts for the preceding taxable year, as well as for the two years prior. The private source funding ratio is calculated based on a percentage of the organization's gross receipts from the preceding taxable year, as well as the two years before. Contributions representing costs allocated to services performed by employees that exceed cash contributions are not considered qualified contributions. Contributions exceeding cash contributions and overhead exceeding 25% of salary/benefits for services by taxpayer's employees are not considered qualified contributions. Contributions to a qualified cooperative research consortium exceeding one-third of the consortium's total nongovernmental support may be eligible for tax benefits. If the consortium has fewer than 5 participants making nongovernmental contributions, special rules apply. If a qualified cooperative research consortium has less than 5 persons making nongovernmental contributions, the qualified contributions of each person shall be reduced by 20 percent if there are 4 persons, or by 40 percent if there are 3 persons. If a qualified cooperative research consortium has less than 5 persons making nongovernmental contributions, the qualified contributions of each person shall be reduced by 20 percent if there are 4 persons, or by 40 percent if there are 3 persons. A qualified cooperative research consortium is an organization registered under the National Cooperative Research Act of 1984, with registration published and in effect on the last day of the organization's taxable year. The Cooperative Research Act of 1984 requires organizations to be registered under the Act with at least 5 contributors, no 3 members contributing more than 80 percent of total nongovernmental contributions, and no single member contributing excessively. The Cooperative Research Act of 1984 mandates registration for organizations with at least 5 contributors, with specific limits on individual and collective contributions. The Cooperative Research Act of 1984 requires registration for organizations with a minimum of 5 contributors, with restrictions on individual and combined contributions. Contributions must not exceed 50% from a single member or 85% from any two members, and contributors must be in the same trade or business. Special rules apply for noncash contributions. Special rules apply for noncash contributions in the same trade or business, including services provided by a taxpayer's employees, which shall be taken into account at their cost. Amounts taken into account should not result in a double benefit. The cost of services provided by a taxpayer's employees, including overhead, should be included in qualified cooperative research expenditures. Contributions to qualified research consortia for research conducted after the taxable year should not result in a double benefit. Prepaid amounts for qualified research conducted after the taxable year in qualified cooperative research consortia are treated as paid or incurred during the research period. Each consortium must report certification, private funding ratio to the Secretary. Each qualified cooperative research consortium must report its certification, private funding ratio, and other required information to the Secretary. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of enactment of this Act.
